awd_abstract_narration:
In telerobotic applications, human operators interact with robots through a computer network. This project is developing tools to prevent security threats in telerobotics, by monitoring and detecting malicious activities and correcting for them. To develop tools to prevent and mitigate security threats against telerobotic systems, this project adapts cybersecurity methods and extends them to cyber-physical systems. Knowledge about physical constraints and interactions between the cyber and physical components of the system are leveraged for security. A monitoring system is developed which collects operator commands and robot feedback information to perform real-time verification of the operator. Timely and reliable detection of any discrepancy between real and spoofed operator movements enables quick detection of adversarial activities. The results are evaluated on the UW-developed RAVEN surgical robot.

This project brings together research in robotics, computer and network security, control theory and machine learning, in order to gain better understanding of complex teleoperated robotic systems and to engineer telerobotic systems that provide strict safety, security and privacy guarantees. The results are relevant and applicable to a wide range of applications, including telerobotic surgery, search and rescue missions, military operations, underwater infrastructure and repair, cleanup and repair in hazardous environments, mining, as well as manipulation/inspections of objects in low earth orbit. The project algorithms, software and hardware are being made available to the non-profit cyber-physical research community. Graduate and undergraduate students are being trained in cyber-physical systems security topics, and K-12, community college students and under-represented minority students are being engaged.

por.por_cntn:
In telerobotic applications such as bomb disposal, remotely operated aircraft, spacecraft, underwater vehicles, search and rescue or robotic surgery, robots serve as extensions of people. Human operators, often geographically distant, interact with robots through a communication channel. For example, a surgical robot that is operated remotely might be used to help patients in locations that do not have timely access to necessary surgeons—such as in remote locations, on the battlefield or after a natural or man-made disaster makes it difficult for surgeons to be on site with the patient. Telerobots allow humans to work with robots in remote or dangerous environments (eg., high temperature, toxic, radioactive or biohazardous situations). It is expected the next-generation telerobotic systems will combine existing, public networks with temporary ad-hoc wireless and satellite networks, to send audio, video and other sensory information to one or more remote operators. The security vulnerabilities of these cyber-physical systems, and methods to prevent them or mitigate the effects of malicious hacking, have received relatively little attention in the research community.

Intellectual Merit: This project developed and demonstrated algorithms and software to enhance the security, privacy and safety of telerobotic systems. The products of this project are tools to prevent security threats in telerobotics; to monitor and detect unexpected and malicious activities; and to correct for errors caused by random failures and malicious actions.

A monitoring system was created and tested, which collects operator commands and manipulator feedback information, and based on the collected data performs a real-time identification of the unique operator's movement features. That is, it recognizes the operator's individual movement signature. A timely and reliable detection of any discrepancy between an authorized and a spoofed operator (or a disabled operator having erroneous movements) enables quick detection of adversarial activities, as well as possible anomalies in teleoperation procedures or operator impairment.

Several possible types of attacks against teleoperated robotic systems were identified, and classified. Each of these classes of attacks were implemented and tested on an example teleoperated robotic surgery system. The impact of these attacks was then assessed. An interesting result is exposure of the tradeoff between real time teleoperation requirements and security needs. For example, the emergency stop button on a robot, placed there for safety, becomes a risk if it can be remotely triggered.

The telerobot operator authentication results of this project were then extended to the more general problem of user authentication. The key idea is that authentication can be made based upon the way that their personal signature is made (in terms of force applied, velocity and graphical), if we use a device with a force sensitive touch screen. This ‘haptic passwords’ approach has applications beyond telerobotic security. For example, it can also be used as an authentication method for on-line transactions, to prevent fraud. Currently the only protection is the three digit code on the back of credit card, which is compromised if someone else has your card or an image of it.

Haptic passwords can also be used for facilities access, secure document signatures and any other situation where identity authentication is needed. It replaces the need to use traditional passwords, which need to be remembered, kept track of and often changed. Unlike other biometrics like finger print readers and retinal scans (many of which have been compromised), haptic passwords provide a secure identity verification based on how you make the signature. This technology can potentially be used for voter identification, on-line voting, or citizen initiative petition signature verification. These haptic passwords have been experimentally demonstrated in this project to be highly forgery resistant, and capable of reliable detection of individual users.

Broader Impacts: This project has brought together different research fields, including robotics, computer and network security, control theory and machine learning, and law and public policy, in order to gain better understanding of complex teleoperated robotic systems, and related security issues. These results enhance the security of telerobotic systems and are relevant to a wide range of applications.

In addition to the impact in the field, provided through publications and presentations and potential use of these results, this project benefits the larger cyber-physical community by broadening our knowledge about the interconnection between the cyber and the physical components of the system.

This project has trained graduate and undergraduate students in the interdisciplinary area of cyber-physical systems security. The education and outreach activities of this project engaged high school, undergraduate and community college students through research opportunities. Members of the project team also participated in outreach activities to encourage middle school and high school students to consider careers in engineering, science and mathematics.
